docs.title: Deficiency / Virtue / Excess
docs.text:
Understanding Intellectual Virtues Through Balance

Intellectual virtues exist on a spectrum. This framework, rooted in Aristotelian virtue ethics, helps us understand that virtues represent a balanced middle ground between two extremes: deficiency (too little) and excess (too much).

docs.title: Curiosity
docs.text:
Apathy (Deficiency)

  • Shows no interest in learning or understanding
  • Asks no questions, even when confused
  • Treats learning as a chore
  • "Whatever, I don't really care"

Example: A student who never wonders about anything beyond what's required for a grade

Curiosity (Virtue)

  • Asks thoughtful, well-timed questions
  • Driven by genuine desire to understand
  • Knows when to stop asking questions
  • Pursues worthwhile subjects, not trivial matters

Example: A learner who asks "Why does this work this way?" and follows up with deeper questions

Nosiness (Excess)

  • Asks questions that invade privacy or boundaries
  • Pursues trivial or salacious information
  • Questions relentlessly without regard for context
  • Driven by gossip rather than genuine understanding

Example: Someone who constantly asks "How much did that cost?" or pries into personal matters

docs.title: Autonomy
docs.text:
Conformity/Dependence (Deficiency)

  • Cannot form independent judgments
  • Simply mirrors others' beliefs
  • Constantly asks "What should I think about this?"
  • Lacks confidence in own reasoning

Example: A person who changes their opinion based on whoever spoke last

Autonomy (Virtue)

  • Forms own judgments and conclusions
  • Uses evidence and reasoning independently
  • Remains appropriately responsive to expert guidance
  • Balances independence with openness to input

Example: A thinker who develops their own perspective but welcomes critique and evidence

Dogmatism (Excess)

  • Refuses to consider others' input or expertise
  • Overly confident in own reasoning
  • Believes they can figure everything out alone
  • Dismisses legitimate authority or expertise

Example: Someone who rejects expert scientific consensus because "I've done my own research"

docs.title: Humility
docs.text:
Arrogance (Deficiency)

  • Refuses to admit limitations or mistakes
  • Defensive when errors are pointed out
  • Believes oneself intellectually superior
  • Obsessed with appearing smart

Example: A person who can never say "I don't know" and makes up answers instead

Humility (Virtue)

  • Aware of and accepts own intellectual limitations
  • Admits mistakes without shame
  • Open to learning from others
  • Neither hides nor obsesses over limitations

Example: A learner who can say "I made a mistake there, thanks for pointing it out"

Servility/Self-Denigration (Excess)

  • Constantly focuses on own limitations
  • Assumes oneself less capable than one is
  • Defers excessively to others
  • "I'm not smart enough to understand this"

Example: A competent student who constantly says "I'm terrible at this" despite evidence otherwise

docs.title: Attentiveness
docs.text:
Distraction (Deficiency)

  • Mind constantly wanders
  • Not mentally present during learning
  • Easily pulled away by any distraction
  • Misses important details and connections

Example: A student who can't recall what was just discussed because they were thinking about other things

Attentiveness (Virtue)

  • Mentally present and focused
  • Notices important details
  • Can concentrate on essential matters
  • Knows when to shift attention appropriately

Example: A learner who is fully engaged in the moment, notices subtle patterns and connections

Hyper-vigilance/Obsessiveness (Excess)

  • Cannot stop focusing on a single thing
  • Notices everything, unable to filter what's important
  • Gets stuck on irrelevant details
  • Paralyzed by overthinking

Example: Someone who fixates on one minor error and can't move forward with their work

docs.title: Carefulness
docs.text:
Carelessness (Deficiency)

  • Makes avoidable errors through sloppiness
  • Doesn't check work for mistakes
  • Rushes to conclusions
  • "Good enough" mentality without pursuing accuracy

Example: A student who submits work without proofreading, filled with obvious errors

Carefulness (Virtue)

  • Strives for accuracy and precision
  • Checks work for errors
  • Avoids hasty conclusions
  • Gets things right without becoming paralyzed

Example: A thinker who reviews their reasoning carefully but knows when work is ready

Scrupulosity/Perfectionism (Excess)

  • Obsesses over potential errors
  • Never satisfied that work is "good enough"
  • Paralyzed by fear of making mistakes
  • Procrastinates due to perfectionism

Example: Someone who rewrites the same paragraph 20 times and never completes their project

docs.title: Thoroughness
docs.text:
Superficiality (Deficiency)

  • Satisfied with surface-level understanding
  • Doesn't probe for deeper meaning
  • Fails to make connections between ideas
  • Cannot explain what they claim to know

Example: A "mere regurgitator" who can repeat facts but can't explain them

Thoroughness (Virtue)

  • Investigates topics in depth
  • Explores connections between ideas
  • Seeks comprehensive understanding
  • Can explain clearly in multiple ways

Example: A learner who doesn't just know the formula but understands why it works

Pedantry (Excess)

  • Insists on exhaustive detail in inappropriate contexts
  • Cannot distinguish important from trivial points
  • Bogs down in minutiae
  • Makes simple things unnecessarily complex

Example: Someone who interrupts every conversation with "Well, actually..." and obscure trivia

docs.title: Open-mindedness
docs.text:
Closed-Mindedness (Deficiency)

  • Refuses to consider alternative viewpoints
  • Rigid, inflexible thinking
  • Dismisses opposing views without consideration
  • "I've made up my mind, don't confuse me with facts"

Example: Someone who won't even listen to perspectives that differ from their own

Open-Mindedness (Virtue)

  • Willing to consider alternative perspectives fairly
  • Can switch viewpoints while maintaining own convictions
  • Gives opposing views honest hearing
  • Knows when to stop considering alternatives

Example: A thinker who seriously engages with views they disagree with before deciding

Gullibility (Excess)

  • Accepts any claim without critical evaluation
  • No stable convictions
  • Cannot distinguish credible from incredible sources
  • Changes mind based on whoever spoke last

Example: Someone who believes every conspiracy theory they encounter because they're "open-minded"

docs.title: Courage
docs.text:
Cowardice (Deficiency)

  • Paralyzed by fear in intellectual contexts
  • Won't speak up even when having valuable insights
  • Avoids intellectual risks at all costs
  • Silenced by fear of being wrong or looking foolish

Example: A student who never raises their hand despite having thoughtful questions

Courage (Virtue)

  • Persists in inquiry despite fear or discomfort
  • Willing to ask difficult questions
  • Speaks up when appropriate despite social risk
  • Manages fear rather than being controlled by it

Example: Someone who shares a controversial but well-reasoned view in a hostile environment

Recklessness (Excess)

  • No appropriate caution in intellectual matters
  • Speaks without thinking
  • Takes foolish intellectual risks
  • Confuses recklessness with courage

Example: Someone who loudly proclaims expertise in areas they know nothing about

docs.title: Tenacity
docs.text:
Laziness/Quick Quitting (Deficiency)

  • Gives up at first sign of difficulty
  • No persistence through intellectual challenges
  • Avoids anything requiring sustained effort
  • "This is too hard, I quit"

Example: A student who abandons a problem after one failed attempt

Tenacity (Virtue)

  • Perseveres through intellectual difficulties
  • Adjusts approach when struggling
  • Embraces intellectual challenges
  • Knows when giving up is actually appropriate

Example: A learner who tries multiple strategies when stuck, learning from each failure

Stubbornness (Excess)

  • Persists with failed approaches
  • Won't give up even when it's clearly not working
  • Cannot recognize when to move on
  • Confuses tenacity with inflexibility

Example: Someone who keeps using the same failed method, refusing to try anything different

docs.title: Using These Scales in Teaching
docs.text:
For Self-Reflection

Ask students: "Where do you tend to fall on each scale? Which extremes do you lean toward?"

For Feedback

Instead of saying "You need more curiosity," say "I noticed you might be leaning toward intellectual apathy here—what questions might you ask?"

For Goal-Setting

"This semester, I'm working on moving from intellectual cowardice toward courage, while making sure I don't become reckless."

For Normalization

These scales show that everyone struggles—we all tend toward one extreme or another at different times. The virtue is the ongoing practice of finding balance.

docs.title: Building a Classroom Culture of Curiosity: A 4-Week Workshop
Overview
docs.text:
This tutorial guides you through a four-week process of intentionally building a classroom culture where curiosity is valued, practiced, and sustained. By the end, your students will have a shared language for curiosity, regular opportunities to practice it, and visible evidence that wondering matters in your classroom.

What you'll learn:

  • How to make curiosity visible and valued in your classroom
  • Concrete routines that practice curiosity daily
  • Ways to sustain curiosity beyond the initial enthusiasm
  • How to recognize and respond to different manifestations of curiosity

Time required: 4 weeks of implementation (15-20 minutes daily)

Important: This is not a unit you teach and finish. It's a foundation you build over four weeks that continues throughout the year.

Prerequisites:

  • You've spent time noticing your own curiosity patterns (see Your First Intellectual Virtue Practice)
  • Basic familiarity with what curiosity is (see Virtues Overview)
  • Willingness to adapt your classroom routines

Before You Begin: What Does a Culture of Curiosity Look Like?

A classroom culture of curiosity is one where:

  • Questions are as valued as answers
  • "I wonder..." is heard as often as "I know..."
  • Students notice things that puzzle them and bring them up
  • Uncertainty is treated as interesting, not embarrassing
  • Time is made for wondering, not just answering
  • The teacher models genuine curiosity, not performed questioning

As Baehr notes, "Curious people wonder about things. They ask thoughtful and insightful questions. They aren't content with easy or pat answers" (Deep in Thought, p. 35). This tutorial helps you create the conditions where that kind of curiosity can flourish.

docs.title: Day 1: Introduce "I Wonder" Language
docs.text:
Task: Introduce the phrase "I wonder" as a sentence stem for curiosity.

How:

  1. Share something you genuinely wonder about related to your subject (not a rhetorical question you already know the answer to).

    Examples:

    • "I wonder why leaves change color at different rates on the same tree"
    • "I wonder why some mathematical patterns show up in nature"
    • "I wonder what it felt like to be an ordinary person during [historical event]"

  2. Explain: "This is called curiosity. It's when we notice something interesting or puzzling and want to understand it better."

  3. Ask students: "What's something you've wondered about recently—about anything at all?"
  4. Write 3-4 student wonders on the board (don't answer them yet)

Why this matters: Naming curiosity and giving students language for it helps them recognize it when it appears. As Baehr notes, "The language of intellectual virtues offers a compelling way of 'thickening' some familiar but elusive educational goals" (p. 18). What success looks like: Students offer at least a few genuine wonders (even if hesitant or off-topic). You resist the urge to immediately answer them.

docs.title: Day 2: Create a "Wonder Wall"
docs.text:
Task: Establish a physical space where wonders can be collected.

How: 1. Designate a bulletin board, wall space, or digital space as your "Wonder Wall" 2. Add your own wonder from yesterday plus 2-3 new ones you've thought of 3. Invite students to add wonders throughout the day/week.

Key rule: No wonder is too big, too small, or too "off-topic" for the Wonder Wall.

Why this matters: Making curiosity physically visible in the classroom signals that wondering is valued, not just tolerated. It creates a shared space for intellectual engagement.

What success looks like: The Wonder Wall starts to fill up. Some students contribute multiple wonders. You add your own regularly (modeling).

docs.title: Day 3: Distinguish Curious from Non-Curious Questions
docs.text:
Task: Help students recognize what makes a question curious versus other purposes.

How:

  1. Look at the Wonder Wall together and pick 2-3 wonders

  2. Contrast them with other types of questions:

    • Curious questions: "I wonder why the sky looks different colors at different times?"
    • Procedural questions: "What page are we on?"
    • Test questions: "What's the capital of France?" (when you're testing, not wondering)
    • Rhetorical questions: "Don't you think that's obvious?"

  3. Explain: "Curious questions come from genuinely wanting to understand. We don't already know the answer, and we care about finding out."

  4. Practice: Give students 3-4 questions and ask, "Which ones sound curious? Why?"

Why this matters: Not all questions reflect curiosity. Students need to distinguish genuine wondering from other questioning behaviors. This builds the skill dimension of curiosity.

What success looks like: Students can identify which questions reflect genuine curiosity and can articulate why.

docs.title: Day 4: Practice Noticing "Wonderable" Moments
docs.text:
Task: Teach students to notice when something is "wonderable."

How: Follow the steps below:

  1. During your regular lesson, deliberately pause when something puzzling or interesting comes up
  2. Say aloud: "This is a wonderable moment. Did anyone else notice something curious here?"
  3. Give 30 seconds of silence for noticing
  4. Collect 2-3 wonders that emerged
  5. Do this 2-3 times during the lesson

Why this matters: Curiosity isn't just about having questions—it's about noticing what's interesting. This builds the attention dimension of curiosity.

Example wonderable moments:

  • An unexpected result in a science experiment
  • A word that sounds strange or contradictory
  • A historical detail that doesn't match expectations
  • A pattern in math that appears unexpectedly
  • A character in a story who acts in a surprising way

What success looks like: Students start to anticipate and notice wonderable moments themselves. Some start saying "This is wonderable!" unprompted.

docs.title: Day 5: Reflect on the Week
docs.text:
Task: Create space for students to reflect on their experience with curiosity.

How:

  1. Ask students to write or discuss:
  2. "What did you wonder about this week?"
  3. "When did you feel most curious?"
  4. "What made it hard to wonder?"
  5. Share some responses (voluntary)
  6. You share too: "Here's what I wondered about this week..."

Why this matters: Reflection helps students recognize curiosity in themselves and begin to see it as a quality worth developing. It also signals that you're curious about their curiosity.

What success looks like: Students can identify at least one moment of genuine curiosity from the week. Some express that they're noticing their own wondering more.

docs.title: Day 1: Introduce "Question Burst" Routine
docs.text:
Task: Teach a structured routine for generating curious questions.

How:

  1. Present a simple object, image, or concept related to your content
  2. Set a timer for 3 minutes

  3. Students generate as many questions as possible about it (no answers, only questions)

    Key rules:

    • No answering questions yet
    • No judging questions as "good" or "bad"
    • Quantity over quality
    • Build on others' questions

  4. After 3 minutes, read through questions and notice what was most wondered about

Why this matters: This routine practices the skill of asking questions without the pressure of needing "good" questions. It builds fluency in wondering.

What success looks like: Students generate 10-15+ questions as a class. Energy and ideas build as they go. Some questions lead to other questions.

docs.title: Day 2: Sort Questions by Type
docs.text:
Task: Help students see that different questions lead to different kinds of understanding.

How:

  1. Take yesterday's questions and sort them into categories:

    • Observational: "What color is it?"
    • Explanatory: "Why is it that color?"
    • Comparative: "How is this different from...?"
    • Hypothetical: "What would happen if...?"
    • Philosophical: "Does this really count as...?"

  2. Discuss: "Which types of questions did we ask most? Which types might lead us deeper?"

  3. Try another Question Burst, but challenge students to ask different types

Why this matters: Virtuously curious thinkers ask questions that are "thoughtful and insightful" (Baehr, p. 35). This helps students develop judgment about which questions lead to understanding.

What success looks like: Students become more diverse and intentional in their questioning. They start to recognize which questions lead somewhere interesting.

docs.title: Day 3: Practice "I Notice / I Wonder"
docs.text:
Task: Introduce a routine that combines observation with curiosity.

How:

  1. Present content (text, image, diagram, problem, etc.)

  2. Students complete two sentence stems:

    • "I notice..." (objective observation)
    • "I wonder..." (curious question arising from what they noticed)

  3. Share several examples

  4. Discuss: How does careful noticing lead to better wondering?

Why this matters: Curiosity often begins with attentiveness. This routine links two virtues: attentiveness (noticing) and curiosity (wondering). See Explanation: How Virtues Support Each Other.

What success looks like: Students' wonders connect clearly to their noticings. They're observing more carefully because they know wondering comes next.

docs.title: Day 4: Create "Wonder Partners"
docs.text:
Task: Establish a system where students wonder together.

How:

  1. Pair students.

  2. Give partners 5 minutes to share:

    • One thing they're currently wondering about (in or out of school)
    • Why it interests them
    • What they've tried to figure out so far

  3. Partners don't solve each other's wonders—they ask follow-up questions to understand the wonder better

  4. Repeat this weekly

Why this matters: Curiosity is social. As Baehr notes, intellectual virtues "are cultivated with others, not alone." Wonder Partners make curiosity collaborative rather than competitive.

What success looks like: Students engage genuinely with their partner's wonders. Some students continue wondering conversations outside of structured time.

docs.title: Day 5: Introduce "The Question Wall Answered"
docs.text:
Task: Begin actually pursuing answers to some wonders.

How:

  1. Look at the Wonder Wall together.

  2. Choose 2-3 wonders that:

    • Multiple students are interested in
    • Are feasible to explore
    • Connect to your content (loosely)

  3. Say: "These wonders matter. Let's find out."

  4. Assign small groups to research one wonder and report back
    • Key rule: Let students determine how to research (books, experiments, interviews, etc.)

Why this matters: Curiosity isn't just about asking questions—it's about actually pursuing understanding. This validates that student wondering leads to real learning.

What success looks like: Students take ownership of investigating their wonders. The answers they discover generate new wonders (curiosity begets curiosity).

docs.title: Day 1: Recognize Different Types of Curiosity in Students
docs.text:
Task: Notice and name the diverse ways curiosity shows up.

How:

  1. Explain: "Curiosity doesn't look the same in everyone. Some people wonder out loud. Some people wonder quietly. Some people wonder through experimenting. Let's notice different types."

  2. Share examples:

    • The student who asks constant questions
    • The student who carefully observes but rarely speaks
    • The student who starts doodling when curious (visual wondering)
    • The student who wants to touch/try things
    • The student who connects everything to something else

  3. Ask: "How do you wonder? What does your curiosity look like?"

Why this matters: Students need to see that curiosity isn't one-size-fits-all. Quieter students may be deeply curious without asking questions aloud. This supports bottom-up, differentiated teaching (see Chapter 3).

What success looks like: Students recognize their own curiosity style. You start noticing and naming curiosity in its diverse forms.

docs.title: Day 2: Address "But What If I'm Not Curious?"
docs.text:
Task: Normalize that curiosity ebbs and flows; address obstacles.

How:

  1. Acknowledge: "Sometimes we don't feel curious. That's normal. Let's talk about why."

  2. Discuss potential obstacles:

    • Feeling overwhelmed or tired
    • Fear of looking stupid
    • Topic feels irrelevant
    • Used to being told answers, not finding them
    • Believing curiosity is only for "smart kids"

  3. Share: When you (the teacher) don't feel curious and what helps

  4. Practice: "What could make [today's topic] wonderable for you?"

Why this matters: As Porter notes, students sometimes have "internal working models" that block virtue development (Chapter 6). Naming obstacles helps remove them.

What success looks like: Students feel permission to not be curious all the time. Some articulate specific obstacles they face. You identify students who might need additional support.

docs.title: Day 3: Practice "What Makes You Say That?" for Curiosity
docs.text:
Task: Teach students to be curious about their own thinking.

How:

  1. When a student shares a wonder, ask: "What makes you wonder about that?"
  2. Model this yourself: "I wonder why birds migrate. What makes me wonder? I noticed some birds are gone now and I realized I don't actually know why they leave."

  3. Practice with students:

    • Student shares a wonder
    • Class asks: "What made you wonder about that?"
    • Student reflects on the source of their curiosity

Why this matters: This builds metacognition—awareness of one's own thinking. It helps students recognize what triggers their curiosity so they can cultivate it intentionally. See Explanation: Metacognition and Epistemic Virtues.

What success looks like: Students can articulate not just what they wonder, but why that particular thing caught their attention.

docs.title: Day 4: Connect Curiosity to Current Learning
docs.text:
Task: Explicitly link student wonders to curriculum content.

How:

  1. Before starting a new unit/topic, ask: "What do you wonder about [topic]?"
  2. Collect wonders visibly (board, chart, digital doc)

  3. Throughout the unit, pause and say:

    • "Remember when Taylor wondered about X? We just learned something about that."
    • "This answers Jordan's question about..."
    • "This creates a new wonder: if this is true, then what about...?"

  4. End unit by revisiting: "Which wonders got answered? Which new wonders emerged?"

Why this matters: This shows students that curriculum isn't separate from curiosity—their wonders matter to what you're teaching. It builds intrinsic motivation (see Chapter 2).

What success looks like: Students see direct connections between their wonders and the curriculum. They start to wonder about curriculum topics before you introduce them.

docs.title: Day 5: Student-Led "Wonder Time"
docs.text:
Task: Give students agency in pursuing their wonders.

How:

  1. Dedicate 20-30 minutes for "Wonder Time"

  2. Students choose:

    • A wonder from the Wonder Wall
    • A new wonder that emerged this week
    • A wonder someone else shared that interests them

  3. They spend time:

    • Researching
    • Experimenting
    • Creating something
    • Discussing with others
    • Going deeper into questions

No required product—the process is the point!

Why this matters: Intellectual autonomy requires students to direct their own inquiry. Wonder Time practices this while keeping curiosity central.

What success looks like: Students are genuinely engaged during Wonder Time. They request more time. They pursue wonders outside of class.

docs.title: Day 1: Create "Wonder Rituals"
docs.text:
Task: Establish small, repeatable routines that keep curiosity alive.

How: 1. Choose 2-3 rituals to implement regularly:

Daily rituals:

- Begin class with "Today's Wonder" (teacher or student shares)
- End class with "What did you wonder about today?"
- "Wonder of the Day" posted on board

Weekly rituals:

- Wonder Partners meet
- "Most Interesting Wonder" voted on by class
- Teacher shares "What I'm Wondering About This Week"

Monthly rituals:

- "Wonder Wall Review"—revisit old wonders, see which got answered
- Guest "Wonder Speaker"—someone shares what they're professionally curious about
- "Wonder Celebration"—share research, projects, or ongoing inquiries

Why this matters: Intellectual virtues are formed through repeated practice over time (see Chapter 8). Rituals make that repetition sustainable.

What success looks like: Rituals become expected parts of classroom routine. Students notice and comment when they're skipped.

docs.title: Day 2: Model Your Own Curiosity (Authentically)
docs.text:
Task: Share your genuine intellectual curiosity with students. How:

  1. Bring in something you're actually wondering about (related or unrelated to class).

  2. Share:

  3. What sparked your wonder

  4. What you've tried to figure out
  5. What still puzzles you

  6. Why you care about understanding this

  7. Invite students to ask you questions about your wondering.

    Key rule: This must be genuine, not performed. Students can tell the difference.

Why this matters: "The power of modeling" (Chapter 9) is central to virtue cultivation. Students learn intellectual virtues from watching adults embody them.

What success looks like: Students see you as a learner, not just a teacher. They ask you genuine questions about your inquiry. Some students adopt similar wondering practices.

docs.title: Day 3: Address "Fake Curiosity"
docs.text:
Task: Help students distinguish genuine from performed curiosity.

How:

  1. Acknowledge: "Sometimes we ask questions because we think we should, not because we really wonder. That's fake curiosity."

    Examples of fake curiosity:

  2. Asking questions to look smart

  3. Asking questions the teacher obviously wants asked
  4. Asking questions to delay work

  5. Asking rhetorical questions ("Isn't that obvious?")

  6. Discuss: "How can you tell when your curiosity is real?"

  7. Emphasize: Genuine curiosity feels like wanting to know, not needing to perform.

Why this matters: Intellectual virtues involve intrinsic motivation (Chapter 2). Students need to distinguish genuine curiosity from performance so they can cultivate the real thing.

What success looks like: Students become more honest about when they're genuinely curious versus going through motions. Quality of questions improves.

docs.title: Day 4: Expand Curiosity Beyond Your Classroom
docs.text:
Task: Help students see curiosity as a lifelong orientation, not just a school skill. How:

  1. Ask: "Where else in your life do you wonder about things?"

  2. Share examples:

  3. Wondering while watching TV/movies

  4. Wondering about how things work (cars, phones, buildings)
  5. Wondering about people (why do they act that way?)

  6. Wondering about yourself (why do I like this?)

  7. Invite: "This week, notice when you wonder outside of school. Bring one wonder back to share."

  8. Create space for sharing these wonders

Why this matters: "The ultimate aim" is to help students become lifelong learners (Chapter 1). Curiosity must extend beyond academic contexts.

What success looks like: Students bring in wonders from home, media, relationships. They see curiosity as part of who they are, not just what they do in school.

docs.title: Day 5: Reflect on Four Weeks
docs.text:
Task: Help students recognize their growth and ongoing journey.

How:

  1. Ask students to reflect (writing or discussion):

  2. "How has your curiosity changed in the past month?"

  3. "What do you wonder about now that you didn't before?"
  4. "What makes it easier or harder to be curious?"

  5. "How do you want to keep growing in curiosity?"

  6. Share your own reflections about the class's growth

  7. Emphasize: "This isn't the end. We've built something we'll keep practicing all year."

Why this matters: Reflection supports metacognition and helps students recognize their own growth. It also signals that virtue cultivation is ongoing, not completed (Chapter 3).

What success looks like: Students can articulate specific changes in how they think and learn. They express interest in continuing the practices. They see themselves as curious people.

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
Over four weeks, you have:

  • Introduced language and routines for curiosity
  • Made wondering visible and valued in your classroom
  • Practiced specific skills (noticing, questioning, pursuing answers)
  • Created sustainable rituals for ongoing curiosity
  • Modeled your own genuine curiosity
  • Built a foundation that will continue all year

This is significant work. You've begun shifting your classroom culture in ways that will benefit students far beyond any single unit of content.

docs.title: Sustaining the Culture: What Comes Next
docs.text:
Continue:

  • Daily/weekly wonder rituals you established
  • Adding to the Wonder Wall regularly
  • Modeling your own curiosity authentically
  • Noticing and naming curiosity in diverse forms

Deepen:

  • Connect wonders to other virtues (humility: "I don't know"; courage: "I'll ask even though it's scary")
  • Use thinking routines that practice curiosity (See-Think-Wonder, etc.)
  • Give students more agency in directing their own inquiry

Expand:

  • Introduce other intellectual virtues using similar processes
  • Help students see how virtues work together
  • Create opportunities for students to reflect on their intellectual character growth

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
For continuing your practice:

  • Tutorial: Facilitating Your First Socratic Seminar
  • How-To Guide: How to Respond When Students Ask Too Many Questions
  • How-To Guide: How to Sustain Curiosity When Covering Required Content

For deepening understanding:

  • Explanation: Why Curiosity is Called the "Fundamental Intellectual Virtue"
  • Explanation: The Relationship Between Curiosity and Deep Learning
  • Reference: Curiosity—Full Description and Examples

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If students aren't contributing wonders:

  • Lower the stakes: model silly or obvious wonders
  • Give thinking time before asking for sharing
  • Use partner talk before whole-class sharing
  • Check: are you inadvertently shutting down wonders by immediately answering them?

If wonders are all off-topic:

  • This is actually fine at first—it shows students feel safe wondering
  • Gradually introduce: "Let's wonder about [today's topic]"
  • Connect their wonders to curriculum when possible
  • Remember: curiosity about anything is better than curiosity about nothing

If you're running out of time:

  • Curiosity practices don't need to be additions—they can replace existing activities
  • A 5-minute wonder routine is better than a 30-minute lecture they'll forget
  • Ask: what am I currently doing that could be cut to make space for this?

If curiosity becomes a performance:

  • Address "fake curiosity" explicitly (Day 3 of Week 4)
  • Stop rewarding questions with praise; simply say "That's a wonder" neutrally
  • Model your own messy, uncertain wondering
  • Make space for silence and for students who wonder quietly

If you feel like you're not curious enough to model this:

  • Return to Tutorial: Your First Intellectual Virtue Practice
  • Start small: find one thing you genuinely wonder about weekly
  • Be honest: "I'm learning to wonder more, just like you"
  • Read: How-To Guide: How to Rekindle Your Own Intellectual Curiosity

docs.title: A Final Word
docs.text:
Building a culture of curiosity is not a project you complete. It's a commitment you make and remake throughout the year.

There will be days when you're too rushed, too tired, or too curriculum-pressured to make space for wondering. That's normal and human.

What matters is that you keep returning to it. That you keep noticing when curiosity appears. That you keep treating student wonders as valuable, not just cute.

As Baehr reminds us: "Curiosity supplies an intrinsic motivation to learn" (p. 35). When you build a culture of curiosity, you're not adding to your teaching—you're creating the conditions where real learning becomes possible.

You're not behind. You're not doing it wrong. You're learning alongside your students.

And that's exactly how it should be.

docs.title: Your First Intellectual Virtue Practice - A 7-Day Self-Awareness Journey
Overview
docs.text:
This tutorial guides you through a week-long practice of noticing your own patterns as a thinker and learner. By the end, you'll have a clearer sense of your intellectual character strengths and areas for growth.

What you'll learn:

  • How to recognize intellectual virtues in your own thinking
  • A sustainable practice for self-reflection
  • The foundation for modeling virtues for others

Time required: 10-15 minutes daily for 7 days

Prerequisites:

  • Basic familiarity with intellectual virtues (see Glossary)
  • A notebook or journal
  • Willingness to observe yourself without judgment

Important: If you are an educator or parent, this practice must come first. You cannot authentically teach or model intellectual virtues you haven't begun to cultivate in yourself.

docs.title: Why Start with Yourself?
docs.text:
Intellectual virtues are not techniques you can apply to students or children. They are habits of mind—stable orientations toward truth, understanding, and inquiry.

As Baehr notes in Deep in Thought, "Good teaching has as much to do with who we are as teachers as it does the instructional methods or practices we employ in the classroom" (p. 3).

This means:

  • You cannot "perform" intellectual virtues on command
  • Children and students learn more from what you embody than what you say
  • Self-cultivation is not preparation for teaching—it IS teaching

Before you try any classroom technique or family conversation about virtues, spend this week learning to notice yourself as a thinker.

docs.title: Day 1: Choose Your Observation Moment
docs.text:
Task: Identify one low-stakes learning situation you'll observe today. Choose something ordinary where you encounter questions, incomplete information, or a gap in your understanding.

Examples:

  • Reading a news article on an unfamiliar topic
  • Listening to someone explain something you disagree with
  • Encounenting a problem you don't immediately know how to solve
  • Helping someone (child or adult) with a question

Key criterion: Choose a situation where you don't feel evaluated or under pressure.

Why this matters: Intellectual virtues reveal themselves most clearly in everyday moments, not high-stakes ones. Start where you can notice patterns without performance anxiety.

Journal prompt for Day 1: What situation did I choose? Why does it feel like a good starting point?

docs.title: Day 2: Notice What Draws You
docs.text:
Task: During today's observation moment, pause and notice your inclinations.

Ask yourself:

  • What do I feel drawn toward in this moment?
  • What am I resisting?
  • Do I want quick answers or am I willing to stay uncertain?
  • Do I want to understand, or do I mainly want to be right/finished/reassured?

Do not judge your answers. Simply notice.

Why this matters: As Baehr explains, intellectual virtues involve both skill and motivation. The motivational dimension—what you genuinely care about when thinking—is foundational. You're beginning to see what drives your intellectual activity.

Journal prompt for Day 2: What did I notice about what I was drawn to or resistant to? Were there any surprises?

docs.title: Day 3: Track Your Response Pattern
docs.text:
Task: Notice how you responded in today's learning moment.

Observe:

  • Did you rush to closure?
  • Did you disengage or distract yourself?
  • Did you stay with uncertainty longer than necessary?
  • Did you immediately defer to someone else (Google, an expert, a friend)?
  • What did you feel? (energized, bored, anxious, curious, defensive, relieved)

Remember: No response is automatically good or bad. You're gathering data, not grading yourself.

Why this matters: Intellectual virtues aren't just about what conclusions you reach—they're about how you move through inquiry. Noticing your patterns is the first step toward any change.

Journal prompt for Day 3: How did I respond today? What does this pattern tell me about my habits as a thinker?

docs.title: Day 4: Begin Naming (Gently)
docs.text:
Task: Try naming one quality you observed in yourself over the past three days. Look back at your journal entries.

Do you see traces of:

  • Curiosity (asking questions, wanting to understand)?
  • Intellectual humility (acknowledging what you don't know)?
  • Intellectual courage (engaging despite discomfort)?
  • Carefulness (checking your thinking, avoiding hasty conclusions)?
  • Open-mindedness (considering alternative views)?
  • Impatience (rushing to closure)?
  • Defensiveness (protecting yourself from being wrong)?

Name it tentatively: "I think I might have been showing traces of..."

Why this matters: As Baehr notes, introducing the language of virtues helps students (and adults) "articulate and practice much of what they already care about" (p. 3). Language helps you see patterns you'd otherwise miss.

Warning: Don't use this language to criticize yourself. You're learning to recognize, not to judge.

Journal prompt for Day 4: What quality or qualities did I glimpse in myself? How did they show up?

docs.title: Day 5: Notice a Contrasting Moment
docs.text:
Task: Deliberately choose a different type of situation today:

  • If you've been observing yourself reading, try observing yourself in conversation.
  • If you've been noticing low-stakes moments, try a slightly higher-stakes one.
  • If you've been thinking about familiar topics, try something unfamiliar.

Use the same observation process from Days 2-3:

  • What are you drawn to or resistant to?
  • How do you respond?

Why this matters: Intellectual virtues (or vices) aren't perfectly consistent across all situations. You might be curious about art but impatient with technology. You might be humble about cooking but arrogant about politics. Noticing context helps you see the full picture.

Journal prompt for Day 5: Did I notice different patterns in this different context? What does that tell me?

docs.title: Day 6: Observe Yourself with Others
docs.text:
Task: Today, notice your intellectual patterns in a social context—a conversation, a meeting, a family discussion.

Pay attention to:

  • When do you speak up? When do you stay silent?
  • Do you listen to understand or to respond?
  • How do you react when someone disagrees with you?
  • Do you ask genuine questions or rhetorical ones?
  • What are you protecting (being right, your image, your time)?

Why this matters: Many intellectual virtues (open-mindedness, humility, courage) are especially visible in how we engage with other people's thinking. Social contexts reveal patterns that solitary thinking might hide.

Journal prompt for Day 6: What did I notice about how I show up intellectually with others? How is it different from how I think alone?

docs.title: Day 7: End with Questions, Not Resolutions
docs.text:
Task: Review your week of observations and end with questions to carry forward. Do not create an action plan. Do not resolve to "be more curious" or "practice more humility." Instead, identify 2-3 honest questions that emerged from your week of noticing.

Examples:

  • What makes it hard for me to stay with uncertainty?
  • When do I feel most alive as a learner?
  • What am I protecting myself from when I disengage intellectually?
  • What kinds of questions or contexts invite the best version of me as a thinker?
  • How might my intellectual patterns affect the learners around me?

Why this matters: Virtue cultivation is not a project with a finish line. It's an ongoing practice of attention. Questions keep you curious and humble. Premature resolutions often become forms of self-judgment when we inevitably fall short.

Journal prompt for Day 7: What 2-3 questions will I carry with me from this week? Why do these questions matter to me?

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
Over seven days, you have:

  • Observed your own intellectual patterns without judgment
  • Begun to recognize traces of virtues (and vices) in yourself
  • Developed a language for noticing intellectual character
  • Created a foundation for authentic modeling

This is genuine progress. Intellectual character development begins with self-awareness, not techniques.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
If you are an educator:

  • Continue this noticing practice informally
  • Consider: Tutorial: Your First Virtue-Focused Lesson
  • Read: Explanation: Why Personal Cultivation Must Come First
  • Explore: How to Model Intellectual Humility as an Educator

If you are a parent:

  • Keep practicing this awareness in daily family life
  • Consider: Tutorial: Starting Epistemic Virtue Conversations at Home
  • Read: Explanation: Formal vs. Informal Education for Epistemic Virtues

For everyone:

  • Read: Explanation: The Three Dimensions of Intellectual Virtues to deepen your understanding
  • Use: Reference: Self-Assessment Tools for a more structured approach
  • Remember: You are not behind. Virtue cultivation is lifelong work.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• If you forgot to observe several days: That's normal and not a problem. Even observing 2-3 moments over seven days is valuable. Start again when you're ready.

  • If you felt frustrated or judgmental toward yourself: This is very common, especially for those who tend toward perfectionism or intellectual arrogance. Notice that self-judgment is also a pattern worth observing—what virtue or vice might it reveal?

  • If you didn't notice much of anything: This might indicate intellectual distraction or a lack of attentiveness as a baseline pattern. Try again with even simpler, shorter moments. Even 30 seconds of observation counts.

  • If this felt pointless or self-indulgent: You might be experiencing resistance to self-reflection, or you might be eager to "get to the real work" with students/children. Remember: without authentic self-cultivation, you'll only be performing techniques, not embodying virtues. Children will sense the difference.

docs.title: A Final Reminder
docs.text:
This tutorial is a beginning, not an end.

Intellectual virtues are cultivated over years, not weeks. They grow through repeated, often small encounters with inquiry—and through our willingness to notice how we show up in those encounters.

You are not expected to master anything here.

You are not being graded.

You are simply learning to pay attention to yourself as a thinker.

That attention is the foundation for everything else this knowledge base offers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This tutorial guides you through planning and facilitating your first Socratic seminar. It is a structured discussion format that practices multiple intellectual virtues simultaneously. By the end, you'll have led a meaningful dialogue where students think together, challenge ideas respectfully, and experience the value of collaborative inquiry.

docs.title: Target Audience: This tutorial is primarily designed for:
docs.text:
What you'll learn:

  • How to prepare for a Socratic seminar
  • Step-by-step facilitation from opening to closing
  • How to recognize and support intellectual virtues during discussion
  • Ways to handle common challenges

Time required:

  • 2-3 hours preparation
  • 45-60 minutes for the seminar itself
  • 15 minutes debrief

Prerequisites:

  • Students have some familiarity with at least 2-3 intellectual virtues (see Building a Classroom Culture of Curiosity)
  • A text, question, or problem suitable for discussion (guidance provided below)
  • Willingness to let students drive the conversation (this is hard!)

Important: Your first Socratic seminar will feel messy. That's normal and actually desirable. The goal is meaningful struggle with ideas, not polished performance.

docs.title: What Is a Socratic Seminar?
docs.text:
A Socratic seminar is a collaborative, intellectual dialogue where students:

  • Explore a complex question or text together
  • Build on each other's thinking
  • Challenge ideas (not people) respectfully
  • Think out loud and change their minds
  • Take responsibility for the quality of the discussion

What it is NOT:

  • A debate (no winners/losers)
  • A teacher-led Q&A (you facilitate, don't dominate)
  • A chance to show who's smartest (it's collaborative, not competitive)
  • A free-for-all (there's structure and purpose)

As Baehr notes, "in many situations, virtuous thinking is a precondition for morally responsible behavior" (p. 24). Socratic seminars practice the virtuous thinking needed for genuine dialogue.

Key virtues practiced:

  • Intellectual humility (acknowledging uncertainty, being open to being wrong)
  • Open-mindedness (seriously considering others' perspectives)
  • Intellectual courage (speaking up, questioning assumptions)
  • Attentiveness (listening carefully to others)
  • Curiosity (asking genuine questions)
  • Intellectual autonomy (forming your own judgments)

docs.title: Two Weeks Before: Selecting Your Text or Question
Task: Choose something worth thinking about together
docs.text:
Good texts for a first seminar:

  • A short story with moral complexity (Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery," Ursula K. Le Guin's "The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas")
  • A thought-provoking article on a relevant issue
  • A primary source document (historical speech, founding document excerpt)
  • A philosophical thought experiment (trolley problem variations)
  • A poem with multiple interpretations
  • A scientific concept with ethical implications
  • A mathematical paradox or puzzle

Or formulate a central question:

  • "What do we owe to people we've never met?"
  • "Is it ever right to break a rule?"
  • "What makes something art?"
  • "Can you ever really know another person?"

Criteria for good seminar material:

  • No single "right answer"
  • Multiple valid interpretations possible
  • Connects to students' lives or genuine questions
  • Rich enough to sustain 45+ minutes of conversation
  • Accessible but not simplistic

What to avoid for your first seminar:

  • Highly controversial current events (emotions may overwhelm thinking)
  • Material requiring extensive background knowledge
  • Texts so complex students can't engage
  • Topics where you have a strong agenda about the "right" answer

Why this matters:

The quality of the discussion depends heavily on the quality of the material. Choose something you're genuinely curious about, not something you want to "teach" them.

docs.title: Day 1: Introduce the Format
docs.text:
Task: Explain what a Socratic seminar is and why it matters.

How: 1. Say something like:

"Next week, we're going to try something called a Socratic seminar. It's named after Socrates, an ancient Greek philosopher who believed the best way to understand something was through dialogue—asking questions and thinking together.

In a Socratic seminar, YOU will lead the discussion. My job is just to help keep it going. Your job is to think together about a question that doesn't have easy answers.

This will probably feel different from regular class discussions. There's no 'right answer' I'm looking for. I'm genuinely curious what you'll discover together."

  1. Explain the basic structure:
  2. We'll sit in a circle (or outer/inner circle for larger classes)
  3. I'll pose an opening question
  4. You'll discuss while I mostly listen

  5. The goal is to think together, not win an argument

  6. Ask: "What feels exciting about this? What feels scary?"

Why this matters:

Students need to understand this isn't a regular class discussion. Setting expectations reduces anxiety and helps them understand their role.

What success looks like:

Students express both interest and nervousness. They understand this will require them to think and speak, not just listen.

docs.title: Day 2-3: Introduce Discussion Norms
docs.text:
Task: Co-create norms for respectful, productive dialogue.

How: 1. Ask: "What makes a discussion feel safe and productive? What makes it feel uncomfortable or pointless?"

  1. Collect student ideas and add essential ones they miss:
  2. Listen to understand, not just to respond
  3. Refer to the text/question, not just opinions
  4. Challenge ideas, not people
  5. Make space for others to speak
  6. It's okay to change your mind
  7. It's okay to say "I'm not sure" or "I need to think about that"
  8. Build on what others say ("Building on what Alex said...")

  9. Ask genuine questions

  10. Frame these as practicing intellectual virtues:

  11. Listening to understand = attentiveness and open-mindedness
  12. Challenging ideas respectfully = intellectual courage and humility
  13. Saying "I'm not sure" = intellectual humility

  14. Building on others = curiosity and thoroughness

  15. Post the norms visibly

Why this matters:

As Baehr notes, "The practice of intellectual rigor in the classroom requires an ethos of trust and acceptance" (p. 169). Co-creating norms builds that ethos.

What success looks like:

Students feel ownership of the norms. They understand these aren't just "rules" but ways of practicing virtues.

docs.title: Day 4: Teach "Talk Moves"
docs.text:
Task: Give students concrete language for participating well.

How: Introduce specific sentence stems:

For building on ideas:

  • "Building on what [name] said..."
  • "That connects to..."
  • "That makes me think of..."

For respectfully disagreeing:

  • "I see it differently because..."
  • "I'm wondering if we could also consider..."
  • "That's an interesting point, and I'm thinking..."

For asking for clarity:

  • "Can you say more about that?"
  • "What do you mean by...?"
  • "Can you point to where you see that in the text?"

For acknowledging uncertainty:

  • "I'm not sure, but I'm thinking..."
  • "I'm still working this out, but..."
  • "That's a good question—I don't know"

For inviting others:

  • "What does everyone else think?"
  • "Has anyone else thought about this?"

Why this matters:

Intellectual virtues require skills (Chapter 2). These talk moves are the skills of virtuous dialogue. Providing language lowers barriers to participation.

What success looks like:

Students practice using the stems. They sound a bit stilted at first—that's fine. Fluency comes with practice.

docs.title: Day 5: Assign the Reading/Preparation
docs.text:
Task: Have students engage with the text or question before the seminar.

How: 1. Provide the text or question

  1. Ask students to prepare by:

  2. Reading/reviewing carefully (perhaps multiple times)

  3. Noting 2-3 passages or ideas that seem important or puzzling
  4. Writing down at least 2 questions the text raises for them

  5. Identifying one place where they're uncertain or could see multiple perspectives

  6. Optional: Use a thinking routine like "I Notice / I Wonder" or "See-Think-Wonder" (see Chapter 8)

  7. Emphasize: "There's no right interpretation I'm looking for. I want to know what YOU think and wonder."

Why this matters:

Preparation supports intellectual autonomy—students form their own thinking before the group discussion. It also ensures everyone has something to contribute.

What success looks like:

Most students come prepared with notes, questions, or marked texts. They've genuinely engaged with the material.

docs.title: The Day Before: Your Final Preparation
Task: Prepare yourself as facilitator
docs.text:
How:

  1. Prepare 3-5 opening questions of increasing depth:

  2. Level 1 (accessible): "What's your first reaction to this text/question?"

  3. Level 2 (analytical): "Where do you see the central tension or conflict?"
  4. Level 3 (interpretive): "What do you think the author wants us to understand?"
  5. Level 4 (evaluative): "Do you agree with the text's assumptions?"

  6. Level 5 (personal/philosophical): "How does this connect to your own experience?"

  7. Identify 2-3 key passages or ideas you hope students will discuss (but don't force)

  8. Prepare follow-up prompts in case discussion stalls:

  9. "Can someone build on that?"

  10. "Does anyone see it differently?"
  11. "Where in the text do you see evidence for that?"

  12. "What questions does that raise?"

  13. Arrange the room: Circle or double circle (inner/outer for large classes)

  14. Prepare materials:

  15. Timer (to track time, not to limit speakers)

  16. Observation sheet if you're taking notes

  17. Copy of the text

  18. Mentally prepare yourself:

  19. Your job is to facilitate, not teach

  20. Silence is productive—don't fill it too quickly
  21. Let students struggle with ideas
  22. Model intellectual humility by being genuinely curious about their thinking

Why this matters: As Baehr emphasizes, teaching postures matter as much as practices (Chapter 4). Your presence, openness, and humility will set the tone.

What success looks like: You feel prepared but not rigidly planned. You're genuinely curious what students will say. You're ready to follow their thinking, not your agenda.

docs.title: Day Of: The Seminar Structure (60 minutes)
Opening (5 minutes)
docs.text:
Task: Set the tone and launch the discussion.

How: 1. Welcome students and acknowledge any nervousness (yours and theirs)

  1. Briefly review norms

  2. Remind them of the goal: "We're here to think together. You'll run this discussion. I'm going to mostly listen and occasionally ask a question. There's no hidden 'right answer' I'm waiting for. I'm genuinely curious what we'll discover together."

  3. Pose your opening question (start with Level 1 or 2)

  4. Give 30-60 seconds of silence for thinking

  5. Invite someone to begin (or ask "Who'd like to start?")

What intellectual virtues look like here:

  • Your humility: "I don't have the answer"
  • Your courage: releasing control
  • Students' courage: being the first to speak

docs.title: Main Discussion (40-45 minutes)
docs.text:
Task: Facilitate while staying mostly in the background.

Your role:

  • Listen actively (model attentiveness)
  • Track who's speaking (notice who's dominating, who's silent)
  • Let silence happen (count to 10 before intervening)
  • Ask clarifying questions when needed
  • Redirect to the text/question if discussion goes off track
  • Name intellectual virtues when you see them

Key facilitation moves:

When discussion is flowing:

  • Do nothing. Just listen and take notes.
  • Make eye contact with students who seem ready to speak
  • Nod to show you're following

When you hear intellectual virtues:

Name them briefly:

  • "That's intellectual courage—questioning an assumption"
  • "I notice intellectual humility—you're acknowledging uncertainty"
  • "That's open-mindedness—seriously considering another view"

When discussion stalls:

  • Wait 10 seconds in silence (it will feel eternal—wait anyway)
  • Then ask: "What are people thinking?" or "Who has a question?"
  • Use your prepared follow-up prompts
  • Refer to a key passage: "What do we make of this part?"

When a few students dominate:

  • "Let's hear from people who haven't spoken yet"
  • "I'm going to wait for some new voices"
  • Make eye contact with quieter students

When someone says something profound:

  • Don't praise effusively (it makes it about you)
  • Instead: "Can someone build on that?" or "What does that make you think?"

When discussion gets heated:

  • Pause and return to the text: "Where do you see evidence for that?"
  • Remind: "We're exploring ideas together, not debating sides"
  • Model: "I'm hearing two different interpretations. Can both be true?"

When you disagree with a student:

  • Resist the urge to correct
  • Instead: "Interesting. Does anyone see it differently?"
  • Or: "What in the text makes you think that?"
  • Remember: your job is to facilitate their thinking, not insert yours

What intellectual virtues look like here:

  • Attentiveness: students listening carefully to each other
  • Intellectual courage: students challenging ideas, admitting confusion
  • Humility: students saying "I don't know" or changing their minds
  • Open-mindedness: students considering views different from their own
  • Curiosity: students asking genuine questions of each other
  • Thoroughness: students probing deeper into ideas

Signs it's going well:

  • Students are talking to each other, not just to you
  • They're using each other's names
  • They're referring to the text
  • There's productive disagreement
  • Some silence for thinking
  • Ideas are building and evolving

Signs of struggle (that are actually okay):

  • Some awkward pauses
  • A few students dominating at first
  • Ideas that go in circles
  • Disagreements that feel uncomfortable

Signs you need to intervene:

  • Personal attacks or disrespect
  • Complete derailment from the topic
  • One student monopolizing for >3 minutes
  • Unsafe silence (>20 seconds with no thinking happening)

docs.title: Closing (10 minutes)
docs.text:
Task: Help students reflect on the discussion and their thinking.

How: 1. Signal the closing: "We have about 10 minutes left. Let's start bringing this together."

  1. Ask a synthesizing question:

  2. "How has your thinking changed?"

  3. "What's still unresolved or puzzling?"
  4. "What was the most interesting idea that came up?"

  5. "Where did we find complexity we didn't expect?"

  6. Give students a few minutes to write:

  7. "What's one thing you're still thinking about?"

  8. "What intellectual virtue did you practice today?"

  9. "What was challenging about this discussion?"

  10. Invite a few to share their reflections

  11. Close with appreciation: "Thank you for thinking together. You practiced intellectual courage, humility, open-mindedness, and curiosity today. That takes real work, and you did it."

What intellectual virtues look like here:

  • Intellectual humility: acknowledging what's still uncertain
  • Metacognition: reflecting on one's own thinking process
  • Intellectual autonomy: articulating one's own evolving views

What success looks like: Students can articulate how their thinking changed or deepened. They recognize they practiced virtues. Some express wanting to do this again.

docs.title: Task: Reflect while it's fresh
docs.text:
How: Within an hour of the seminar, write notes:

About the discussion:

  • What went well?
  • What surprised you?
  • Where did students really think together?
  • Where did it stall or struggle?

About intellectual virtues:

  • Which virtues did you see students practicing?
  • Which students showed unexpected strengths?
  • Where did you see growth?

About your facilitation:

  • When did you intervene too much or too little?
  • What postures helped or hindered?
  • What would you do differently next time?

About next steps:

  • What follow-up would be valuable?
  • What do students need to practice more?
  • When will you do another seminar?

Why this matters: Reflection supports your own growth as a facilitator. You'll learn as much from the first seminar as your students did.

docs.title: Task: Help students process the experience
docs.text:
How: 1. Ask students to reflect (writing or discussion):

  • "What was different about the Socratic seminar compared to regular discussions?"
  • "What intellectual virtues did you practice? Which was hardest?"
  • "What did you learn from hearing others' ideas?"

  • "What would help you participate more fully next time?"

  • Share your observations:

  • Name specific moments when you saw virtues in action

  • Acknowledge challenges: "I noticed it was hard when..."

  • Express genuine curiosity: "I was surprised when you all..."

  • Co-create improvements:

  • "What would make our next seminar even better?"

  • "What do we need to practice?"

  • Commit to doing it again:

  • "This is a practice we'll keep developing"

  • "Each seminar will feel different as we get better at this"

Why this matters: As Baehr notes, "Reflection and self-awareness" support virtue development (Chapter 6). Debriefing helps students recognize what they practiced and how they can grow.

What success looks like: Students recognize specific intellectual virtues they practiced. They identify areas for growth. Most express interest in trying again.

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
You have:

  • Planned and facilitated a complex, student-centered discussion
  • Created an opportunity for students to practice multiple intellectual virtues simultaneously
  • Modeled intellectual humility by stepping back and facilitating rather than directing
  • Begun building students' capacity for virtuous dialogue
  • Taken a significant risk as an educator (releasing control is hard!)

This is major growth work—for you and your students.

docs.title: Planning Your Next Seminar
docs.text:
Keep doing:

  • Thorough preparation (text selection, questions, logistics)
  • Clear norms and expectations
  • Facilitating rather than dominating
  • Naming virtues when you see them

Try differently:

  • Based on your reflection, adjust one aspect of facilitation
  • Experiment with inner/outer circle if you haven't
  • Try a different type of text or question
  • Give students more ownership (they pose questions, they facilitate)

Build toward:

  • More frequent seminars (monthly → bi-weekly → weekly)
  • Student-led facilitation
  • More complex texts and questions
  • Cross-curricular seminars
  • Seminars focused on specific virtues

docs.title: For younger students (elementary):
docs.text:
• Shorter seminars (20-30 minutes)
  • Picture books or short fables as texts
  • More structured turn-taking at first
  • Very concrete norms and talk moves
  • More frequent check-ins during discussion

docs.title: For larger classes:
docs.text:
• Inner/outer circle structure (half discuss while half observe)
  • Switch halfway through
  • Observers note examples of intellectual virtues they see
  • Smaller group seminars that rotate

docs.title: For online/hybrid contexts:
docs.text:
• Use breakout rooms for smaller seminars
  • Chat for quieter students to contribute
  • Digital collaborative document for note-taking
  • Recording for later reflection (with student permission)

docs.title: For students new to discussion:
docs.text:
• Start with "mini-seminars" (15-20 minutes)
  • Very simple texts or questions
  • More scaffolding and structure initially
  • Gradually release responsibility

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
For continuing Socratic seminars:

  • How-To Guide: How to Handle Difficult Moments in Socratic Seminars
  • How-To Guide: Moving Students Toward Peer Facilitation
  • Reference: 50 Questions for Socratic Seminars Across Disciplines

For deepening understanding:

  • Explanation: Why Socratic Dialogue Cultivates Intellectual Virtues
  • Explanation: The Relationship Between Dialogue and Deep Understanding
  • Reference: Rubrics for Assessing Seminar Participation

For connecting to other practices:

  • Tutorial: Building a Classroom Culture of Curiosity
  • How-To Guide: How to Facilitate Feedback That Cultivates Epistemic Virtues

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If students won't talk:

  • Wait longer in silence (truly count to 15)
  • Use think-pair-share before whole group
  • Start with partner discussions
  • Lower stakes: "Turn to someone and share what you're thinking"
  • Check: did they actually prepare? Do they understand the text?

If a few students dominate:

  • Directly invite others: "Let's hear from people who haven't spoken yet"
  • Use inner/outer circle structure
  • Give everyone a set number of "talking chips"
  • Acknowledge dominance kindly: "I can see you have more to say, and I want to make space for others"

If discussion becomes an argument:

  • Pause: "Let's step back. What are we really asking here?"
  • Return to text: "Where do you each see evidence?"
  • Reframe: "It sounds like you're exploring two different interpretations. Can both be true?"
  • Model: "I notice this is getting heated. How can we explore these ideas with intellectual humility?"

If you can't stay quiet:

  • Literally sit on your hands
  • Count to 10 before speaking
  • Give yourself a limit: "I will speak maximum 5 times"
  • Have a trusted colleague observe and signal when you're over-talking

If the discussion goes off-topic:

  • Gently redirect: "That's interesting. How does it connect to our question?"
  • Ask: "Are we still exploring the same question, or have we moved to a new one?"
  • Return to text: "Let's look back at [passage]. What does this tell us?"

If students say superficial things:

  • Ask: "Can you say more about that?"
  • Probe: "What in the text makes you think that?"
  • Invite others: "Can someone build on or complicate that idea?"
  • Model thoroughness: "That's a start. What else might we consider?"

If you feel like it was a disaster:

  • Remember: your first seminar will be messy—that's normal
  • Ask: Did students think at all? (If yes, it wasn't a disaster)
  • Debrief with students—they may have experienced it differently
  • Learn from it and try again—each one gets better

docs.title: A Final Word
docs.text:
Your first Socratic seminar will not be perfect.

You will talk too much or too little. Students will go off-topic. There will be awkward silences. Someone will say something you disagree with and you'll struggle not to correct them.

All of this is normal.

What matters is that you created a space where students had to think—really think—together. Where they practiced intellectual virtues not by hearing about them, but by doing them.

As Baehr reminds us, "Intellectual virtues are formed through repeated practice over time" (Chapter 8). This seminar is one practice session. There will be many more.

Each seminar will be different. Each one will teach you something. Each one will help your students grow as thinkers.

You're not behind. You're not doing it wrong.

You're learning alongside your students, which is exactly what intellectually humble educators do.

And that's the best modeling you can offer.
